awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Geochemical and Biochemical Factors Controlling Skeletal Nucleation and Their Impact on Coral in a Changing Ocean
awd_abstract_narration:
Nucleation is the first step needed to form calcium carbonate crystals from a seawater solution and represents the building block of coral skeletons.   Recently, the pH of the ocean has become more acidic which can impact nucleation, and as such, coral growth.  This research will measure nucleation rates under a variety of controlled conditions to identify the important processes controlling skeletal nucleation kinetics, namely environmental, biochemical, or some combination of the two.  Additionally, the project will merge science and education in new ways to help improve the diversity in Earth Sciences by increasing the participation of Native American students in oceanography. Partnering with an Anthropology professor at the University of Washington, the scientist will develop a class on how geology and oceanography teaches us about how the oceans have changed over time, how different cultures have adapted to these changes, and consider human?s future on a changing planet.  Four undergraduate students taking the class will be eligible for summer internships to participate in the research project.  

Coral skeletal nucleation is only possible if dissolved ions can overcome an energetic barrier to self-assemble into a calcified structure. The magnitude of this barrier is controlled by the aragonite saturation state and interfacial energy, meaning that nucleation is a product of both geochemical and biochemical controls that are currently not well constrained. Coral paleoproxies have been widely used to study environmental processes through deep time, and therefore, understanding of the initial step, nucleation, should greatly further understanding of the use and applicability of coral paleoproxies. The researcher's group has developed a nucleation assay to measure in vivo nucleation rates. This will be used under a variety of controlled conditions to measure the impact of the biochemical and geochemical controls on nucleation. Under the pressures of changing ocean chemistry due to ocean acidification, it is likely that nucleation rates will be greatly impacted, and it is crucial to begin developing knowledge on the magnitude of the effect ocean acidification will have on coral skeletal nucleation.

por.por_cntn:
The chemistry of the ocean is changing. How marine organisms adapt to these changes and whether there are fundamental limits to this adaptive capacity will shape the future ocean. These questions are especially important for marine calcifiers like corals because the thermodynamic stability of their skeletal material (CaCO3) is decreasing with ocean acidification.

Corals build their skeletons through a repeated cycle of CaCO3 nucleation followed by mineral growth upon these nuclei. Nucleation acts as a gatekeeper, controlling the location and timing of skeletal growth in both juvenile and adult corals, with implications for net skeletal growth rates in a changing ocean. Despite the importance of this process, the energetics and regulation of nucleation is poorly understood in corals. Indeed, the same characteristics that allow nucleation to act as a useful physiological checkpoint, namely large energy barriers coupled with high-order sensitivity to local chemistry, also imply that nucleation should be exceptionally sensitive to environmental conditions like ocean acidification. A critical question facing both scientists and ecosystems is whether organisms that are sensitive to changing ocean conditions can adapt and whether there are fundamental limits to this adaptive capacity. In the case of nucleation, we determine the mechanisms controlling adaptive capacity at a chemical scale to understand how this essential process will change in a future ocean.

We conducted inorganic nucleation rate experiments under controlled chemical conditions and determined the rate law governing this process in seawater like solutions. We showed that the nucleation step of skeletal growth is more sensitive to saturation state, which decreases with ocean acidification, than the mineral growth step. Using these data we developed a numeric model of coral calcification and showed that horizontal extension of the skeleton is especially sensitive to changes in nucleation rate. The relationship between nucleus density and lateral growth rates predicted by our model was then confirmed in cultured tropical corals. The sensitivity of lateral growth to ocean acidification implied by our model has ecological implications for corals as they fight for space on crowded reefs in a changing ocean.

We then determined the role that coral matrix proteins play in controlling skeletal nucleation. We found that these proteins switch dramatically from inhibiting nucleation to accelerating nucleation above a certain saturation state. This feature can help corals control when and where nucleation occurs but it can also accentuate the impacts of ocean acidification on skeletal growth. Because of the importance of saturation state on skeletal growth we completed complementary experiments using boron isotopes to infer the saturation state of the calcifying fluid in corals. Collectively, our experiments indicate how skeletal growth in corals responds to environmental changes like ocean acidification, the limits to adaptive capacity, and the cost of resilience.

Broader Impacts: This proposal integrated educational and research efforts through the development of training workshops for high school chemistry teachers. The workshops provided foundational information and example lessons to help teachers incorporate climate science into their chemistry curriculum so they could meet Next Generation Science standards, with a focus on ocean acidification.

A new undergraduate Indigenous Science course was co-developed by faculty in Oceanography and Anthropology. The course was designed to recruit a broad group of students into oceanography and earth science. To do this we expanded the scope of traditional scientific education to include how indigenous communities contribute to and are impacted by research. We also used case studies from the Pacific Northwest to anchor the science and student experience in a sense of place. Students were recruited from outside of earth and ocean science majors. As assessed by pre- and post-course attitudinal surveys, at least a third of students shifted from being uninterested in pursing further earth science education to wanting to take more earth science courses. Courses like this are a way to broaden the types of students we teach in STEM fields and to broaden the diversity of concepts that inform faculty scholarship.

In addition to training several undergraduate researchers, this proposal supported a female graduate student while she completed a PhD in Oceanography with an extra Advanced Data Science credential. This rigorous computer science program trains the next generation of the STEM workforce to become thought leaders in data science and machine learning.
